pr_title: JUnit parser performance tests for 1k tps record files

timeline.message:
Junit parser performance tests for 1k tps record files

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Add circle ci maven_ perf stage

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Updated circleci config with restore and save maven_cache. Also moved perf to end

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Added missing checkout step for perf_maven

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

timeline.bodyText:
can be assigned to a yaml alias for reuse in job build_maven
similarly the docker params below.
For eg
references:
  maven_docker: &maven_docker
      docker:
        - image: adoptopenjdk:11-jdk-hotspot
        - image: postgres:9.6-alpine
          environment:
            POSTGRES_DB: mirror_node_test
            POSTGRES_PASSWORD: mirror_node_pass
            POSTGRES_USER: mirror_node

and then here
-*maven_docker
timeline.author: apeksharma

timeline.bodyText: version in properties like other deps.
timeline.author: apeksharma

replies.bodyText: You shouldn't need to hardcode it, let it inherit from spring boot if possible
replies.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: do we want to keep this general (and add balance tests here in future) or keep it just for record and isolate balance test in other class?
timeline.author: apeksharma

replies.bodyText: It should be record specific. Recommend adding Record to name
replies.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: I envisioned multiple classes, so the later.
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.bodyText: we can make filter string a param and move rest of the code here to parse(..) too
timeline.author: apeksharma

timeline.bodyText:
imo, running it for every commit might be overkill right now since it doesn't need to be run for grpc, rest, and most general commits. That said, perf regressions can creep in unexpectedly. So maybe later on, we should setup to run perf test in nightly/periodic manner.
up to you, just suggestion.
timeline.author: apeksharma

replies.bodyText: I think the goal was to have it run every time to not miss something
replies.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: Agreed though a nightly run instead with maybe larger datasets would be a good idea also
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.bodyText:
imo, just this one  is enough.
Others will have too less of runtime and data (data point for single file) to be of much significance.
Just this test is perfect, one run of this will be good enough data point to be significant since it's ingesting multiple files(so in a way, it's aggregate of multiple data points), and running for extended time.
Up to you, just a suggestion.
timeline.author: apeksharma

replies.bodyText:
I thought the 5000 and 10000 case might offer smaller units that you can use to estimate performance when you're not able to run tests or need to do a quick estimate e.g. we've seen 5k use of a record file produced at 1k tps take x, so in y scenario it might take z.
Granted this assumes linear relationship which may not hold with the the table indexes
replies.author: Nana-EC

replies.bodyText: We don't need to worry about non-automated use cases like quick estimates. Goal here is to push multiple files through to validate performance doesn't regress  and run those tests on every commit or nightly if tests take too long to run.
replies.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Reduced it to the single one
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.bodyText: It's more important to run cleanup before than after, but can just add both
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: Recommend just using @Timeout on each test method and removing this parse method. Logging not necessary
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: There should be some sort of warmup in a @BeforeAll or @BeforeEach to get accurate performance numbers
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: These files should be in a different folder than the normal v1 and v2 tests. Suggestion: src/test/resources/data/recordstreams/performance/. It doesn't need the name of the node account id.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.bodyText: I would like to see JUnit tags used to find performance tests instead of properties. That is, go ahead and run both unit and integration tests and configure excludedGroups to be !performance. We could potentially have unit tests that micro benchmark classes that we want to run as part of this profile too.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Sure, I had tried this earlier but hit some snags in the multiple goal instances. I can revisit it
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.bodyText: @Tag("performance"). Also, since most of our tests can be considered integration tests (they all extend IntegrationTest and start a DB), can we rename this to end in test? I think if you use groups and tags to include/exclude maven failsafe it should pick that suffix up.
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

replies.bodyText: Same comment as above. Had tried with a @tag("benchmark") with no luck but might have been blocked by other issues. Will revisit to get it working.
replies.author: Nana-EC

timeline.message:
Reduced perf test down to 60k transactions. Renamed file with Record.

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Utilized junit5 tag feature instead of pom properties to filter

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Used special mapping keys for docker alias in circle ci yaml

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

Fixed parseAndIngestMultipleFiles60000Transactions test calling single file

Signed-off-by: Nana-EC <56320167+Nana-EC@users.noreply.github.com>

timeline.bodyText: These can be removed now, I believe
timeline.author: steven-sheehy

timeline.message:
Removing skip.integration.tests and skip.unit.tests properties that are no longer used
